9. Purple next to green has no ill grace,
Blue and purple greet each other well,
but red does not sit so well near flesh tone,
for the nude prefers to converse
with green, blue, or purple if they meet.
Blue is good next to green, if one is attentive
to softening the transitions. One will do well
working with different reds or yellows.
right-middleThat it looks right to place colors together which are not contrary.

10. That is, rosy yellow and greenish yellow
next to one another, and blue-purple
and reddish purple, or other mixtures.
But Bruegel, whose works are full of life,
often made Fabrics in different half tonesâ€“
yes, shadowed almost without shadow,
and among all those muted tones,
a blooming azure, or red glowing like fire.
right-middleExample of Bruegel, making some beautiful colors stand out among many half tones.

11. This is like the Poets, who sometimes
compose long discourses and histories
to delight us by tickling our ears,
and in the meantime, slip in
a Saying full of sense, worthy of pondering.
Or more precisely, it is like the Peacock,
with its lovely feathers, or Indian Birds,
outstanding among other Birds.

12. On occasion we might make use of this.
I recall that a group of young Painters
were working in the Belvedere Palace.
Raffaelino da Reggio used many pale half tones
for his figures, unlike the bright colors sought by others;
but no honey-seeking Bees could rush to the Thyme
as fast our eyes fly happily to his works,
before looking at others.
right-middleThe Example of Raffaelino da Reggio, on making many half tones.

div.ab:
13. I could speak of more conditions
in varying colors which the Painter
will encounter along the way at some time:
to know how to distinguish the ground color
in nudes and clothing, according to their natures.
That also to place all objects in proper contrast
in Landscape and architecture,
in order to combine all colors well.

14. However, after what you have read, take from it
and embellish as you think best.
Indeed, this great work often makes me lose heart,
and I gaze, like Phaeton in his chariot,
sometimes to the East, sometimes to the West,
to see if, after a long race, I may not at last
right-middleI long for the end of this difficult work.
